data.title: Final Results
data.full_content:
24 Aug 2020 07:00
RNS Number : 8899W
Marechale Capital PLC
24 August 2020
24
August 2020
Marechale Capital plc
("Marechale" or the "Company")
Consolidated Financial Statements for the year ended 30 April 2020
Marechale is pleased to announce its final results for the year ended 30 April 2020.
Chairman's statement
Marechale Capital is an established corporate finance firm providing strategic, M&A and advisory services primarily to hospitality and renewable companies in the UK and Europe. Marechale also finances earlier stage and growth capital companies from its family office, private investor and private equity relationships.
A year ago we took the difficult decision to significantly reduce our cost base in order to deliver an annual profit and we were on-track to doing so before the Covid lockdown stopped most commercial activity, and specifically investments. Traditionally we earn a significant proportion of our annual revenues in the last quarter, much of it
tax driven growth investments, which affected our March and April revenues, and meant that we missed our target. Our business, which is predominantly hospitality advisory and growth finance has since been affected by the coronavirus.
Marechale's revenues for the year of £477,000 (2019: £512,000) were slightly down on last year, but because of lower third-party commissions, we delivered a higher Gross Profit of £422,000 (2019: £400,000).
Administrative expenses were reduced to £447,000 from £688,000 in 2019.
Whilst the Company was not profitable for the year as hoped, the business delivered an operating loss of £25,000, significantly better than the £288,000 loss in 2019.
Investments in two client companies realised gains of £19,350 which were offset by the need to write off £20,850 for an investment now in liquidation, producing a net overall loss of £1,500 compared to £22,000 of gains in 2019.
The Company has raised equity and debt funding for a number of new and existing clients. This included funding for the telecommunications business Fast2fibre and raising capital for The Forest Road Brewing Company for their new brewery. Funding for existing clients include leading gastropub group Brewhouse & Kitchen, and the craft spirits distiller Oslo Distillery to finance their further development and product launch into the United States. Additionally, the Company has completed advisory work for a wide range of consumer brand, hospitality and renewable energy businesses.
In accordance with IFRS9 Equity Investments and Warrants are valued at 'fair value', typically at a price that reflects their last funding round, and underlying movement in fair value is reflected through the Profit and Loss Account. Given our Investments and Warrants are held, broadly speaking, in the Renewables and in the Hospitality sectors, where under Lockdown the former continued to trade but the latter were closed, with potential well publicised difficulties to re-open, the Board was forced to consider re-valuing the latter at 30 April 2020, rather than two months earlier in healthier times. The Board determined to make a 50% 'Covid 19' downward fair value adjustment of £11,000 (2019: 'non Covid' of £30,000) against all our Hospitality Investments and Warrants in the sincere hope that these may be recovered this time next year.
The net effect is a loss for the year before tax of £37,500 compared to a £298,000 loss in 2019.
The balance sheet value has reduced during the year to £159,000 (2019: £179,000) which is more fully explained in the Statement of Changes in Equity.
Finally, it will come as no surprise that current trading is very challenging as there is concern and lack of confidence in the Hospitality sector, nonetheless the Directors are confident that markets will recover. While there is increasing optimism that the worst of Covid is over, there is significant uncertainty as to the timing and extent of any recovery.
Mark Warde-Norbury
Chairman
21 August 2020

data.author: roger65
data.content: Think that’s a highly likely link SW. good spot. This will only help attract investment into Weardale’s project. I wonder if Nissan could be a potential partner for offtake given their car plant is also close. Ducks are aligning, albeit very slowly.

data.author: roger65
data.content: Nissan's requirement for battery grade lithium will be in the thousands of tons per year. Their plant is in Sunderland so only c35 miles away. Given Nissan's scaling up with its Gigafactory expansion and the UK's broader EV transition there just has to be a massive opportunity here for the north. Why is the UK Govt so slow to help this happen? I think it absolutely WILL happen but quite frankly the need for this stuff in the ground is urgent as it is and building a plant will take 18 - 24 months so why is no one moving on it NOW? I am seriously tempted to quit my various trading stocks and go all in on this with my trading pot. Not much but it would take my holding up to nearly £50k. The appeal is all in Weardale and the huge rise in the spot price of lithium which imho is set to continue well into 2026 before settling on or around the £25k - £30k mark per ton. Producing 10,000 tons per annum gives a potential revenue of £300m pa. Even after all costs are dealt with that's a massive investment opportunity. Someone WILL definitely snap this up. Only question is who.

It would actually alert the market to something going on so someone may as well make their move and go in for the kill and just conisder it a bonus that they get a quick and cheap Listing on LSE

Having thought about this recently I feel it’s more likely that SE just do a takeover of MAC would still be cheap and current share holders will hopefully walk away with rather more than their investments are currently worth here. If SE wanted a listing they’d have one by now so I think it’s just the 8% stake in the Weardale project they might be interested in and they wish to add it to their portfolio of investments. Current mcap of MAC is less than £3m. So propose buying it for say £6m - needs to be fairly decent or share holders might vote against it but between the directors they have over 30% of the company under their control. £6m for an 8% stake in a lithium project that is going to generate approx £160m of revenue (not profit) at existing lithium prices. I’d say that’s a very decent result for SE. I’d prefer to see the share price closer to 5p before an offer is made for obvious reasons but what ever happens I’m hopeful existing share holders might do well from this point in time.

Given Nissan's scaling up with its Gigafactory expansion and the UK's broader EV transition there just has to be a massive opportunity here for the north. Why is the UK Govt so slow to help this happen? I think it absolutely WILL happen but quite frankly the need for this stuff in the ground is urgent as it is and building a plant will take 18 - 24 months so why is no one moving on it NOW? I am seriously tempted to quit my various trading stocks and go all in on this with my trading pot. Not much but it would take my holding up to nearly £50k. The appeal is all in Weardale and the huge rise in the spot price of lithium which imho is set to continue well into 2026 before settling on or around the £25k - £30k mark per ton. Producing 10,000 tons per annum gives a potential revenue of £300m pa. Even after all costs are dealt with that's a massive investment opportunity. Someone WILL definitely snap this up. Only question is who.

I had the pleasure of sitting down with Stewart Dickson, a former investment banker who is now leading one of the UK’s most ambitious clean-energy projects. As CEO of Weardale Lithium, he is driving plans to extract lithium from deep beneath County Durham and create the country’s first home-grown supply of this critical battery metal. The numbers are staggering. The project could produce up to 10,000 tonnes of battery-grade lithium carbonate each year, enough to power around 250,000 electric vehicles, inject more than £1 billion into the regional economy and support over 125 high-value jobs.

data.content: ‘It is worth noting…’ is a favourite phrase of the clown who puts MAC’s RNSs together. How long ago did he say that and what news has there been since? None. The kind of leaders who take risks and turn ideas into game-changing, real-world impact. I had the pleasure of sitting down with Stewart Dickson, a former investment banker who is now leading one of the UK’s most ambitious clean-energy projects. As CEO of Weardale Lithium, he is driving plans to extract lithium from deep beneath County Durham and create the country’s first home-grown supply of this critical battery metal. The numbers are staggering. The project could produce up to 10,000 tonnes of battery-grade lithium carbonate each year, enough to power around 250,000 electric vehicles, inject more than £1 billion into the regional economy and support over 125 high-value jobs.

data.author: roger65
data.content: Lithium carbonate prices dropping. Looks like Stewart Dickson of Weardale, for all his banking experience, seems to have failed to move Weardale forward since last year and no partners on the horizon. All suggests Weardale (and MAC’s 8% ) are likely going to be snapped up by northern lithium imho. If that’s who the uk Govt decide to support up north then it’s game over for Marechale as they have made a loss do several years in a row now and the only one with any real potential was this one in Weardale. News soon or it just collapses. Directors buddies who put £50k in Oct won’t be best pleased but maybe that was just punt money to them. An awful lot of money has exited MAC in the last month & all in the midst of several trading flurries that are rarely for more than £10. Loads of them all at once spikes the sp and then hey presto someone manages to dump £10k at a higher price. Been going on for weeks now so I personally think someone knows what’s on the cards and is making their escape.

data.content: That’s a year old p2r! There’s been no news on any funding from private sector or govt. I could see an offer of £30m for Weardale being accepted (10x their current valuation) and that would hopefully mean our 8% would be worth a share price of something nearer the region £2.5m on top of current sp. So basically double where it is now. I would be thrilled with 100% from here as I’ve now got rather a lot of these shares.

data.author: Potential2Rise
data.content: Https://www.linkedin.com/posts/richardjhogg_weardale-lithium-a-1-billion-plus-vision-ugcPost-7394636622744662016-jjgR?utm_source=social_share_send&utm_medium=member_desktop_web&rcm=ACoAABbFtmABMjzjNDtSx_jOM0H2QE2S5Mt_PPI If one can't access LinkedIn read this below View profile for Richard Hogg Richard Hogg  3rd+ CEO at Jackson Hogg | Co-Founder River Birch Newman | Jackson James | Tecuna 2mo  Edited Follow Weardale Lithium - A £1 Billion Plus Vision I go to numerous meetings where we talk about the need for people with big visions. The kind of leaders who take risks and turn ideas into game-changing, real-world impact. I had the pleasure of sitting down with Stewart Dickson, a former investment banker who is now leading one of the UK’s most ambitious clean-energy projects. As CEO of Weardale Lithium, he is driving plans to extract lithium from deep beneath County Durham and create the country’s first home-grown supply of this critical battery metal. The numbers are staggering. The project could produce up to 10,000 tonnes of battery-grade lithium carbonate each year, enough to power around 250,000 electric vehicles, inject more than £1 billion into the regional economy and support over 125 high-value jobs.

data.author: Potential2Rise
data.content: Https://www.linkedin.com/posts/richardjhogg_weardale-lithium-a-1-billion-plus-vision-ugcPost-7394636622744662016-jjgR?utm_source=social_share_send&utm_medium=member_desktop_web&rcm=ACoAABbFtmABMjzjNDtSx_jOM0H2QE2S5Mt_PPI If one can't access LinkedIn read this below View profile for Richard Hogg Richard Hogg  3rd+ CEO at Jackson Hogg | Co-Founder River Birch Newman | Jackson James | Tecuna 2mo  Edited Follow Weardale Lithium - A £1 Billion Plus Vision I go to numerous meetings where we talk about the need for people with big visions. The kind of leaders who take risks and turn ideas into game-changing, real-world impact. I had the pleasure of sitting down with Stewart Dickson, a former investment banker who is now leading one of the UK’s most ambitious clean-energy projects. As CEO of Weardale Lithium, he is driving plans to extract lithium from deep beneath County Durham and create the country’s first home-grown supply of this critical battery metal. The numbers are staggering. The project could produce up to 10,000 tonnes of battery-grade lithium carbonate each year, enough to power around 250,000 electric vehicles, inject more than £1 billion into the regional economy and support over 125 high-value jobs.
